hh.text: Divine Shield After a friendly minion loses Divine Shield, gain +2 Attack.
hh.name: Bolvar, Fireblood
hh.flavor_text: He's so hot right now.
hh.guide:
Bolvar, Fireblood is a Legendary Paladin class card from Knights of the Frozen Throne expansion. It is a five-mana 1/7 minion with Divine Shield that gains two Attack after a friendly minion loses Divine Shield.

Because the previous version of Bolvar Fordragon (from Goblins vs Gnomes) was buffed while it was in your hand, people sometimes confuse the way these two cards work. Bolvar, Fireblood does not get buffed when it is not on the board. It gains two Attack while it is on the board and a friendly minion loses Divine Shield.

Note that as Bolvar has Divine Shield of its own, it also buffs itself after it loses the Divine Shield. Therefore, the first attacker will hit a one-attack Bolvar, but the next one has to face a three-attack Bolvar.

The five-mana slot is relatively dry for Paladin – there are practically no useful class cards in that mana slot for Paladin, except for Grimestreet Enforcer for handbuff decks – and there is a certain Spikeridged Steed waiting at six mana, so Bolvar is quite an attractive on-curve play. With seven health and a Divine Shield, it is extremely difficult to kill for its mana cost.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

Blood Knight can buff itself and Bolvar simultaneously by removing Divine Shields from minions. Whether this is actually worth removing those Divine Shields is another question though.

Standard Format

Bolvar, Fireblood is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in spring 2019.

Paladin has access to a number of minions with Divine Shield, so the tools to build a deck that can buff Bolvar, Fireblood exist:

  • Tirion Fordring
  • Argent Commander
  • Sunwalker
  • Bolvar, Fireblood
  • Psych-o-Tron
  • C'Thun's Chosen
  • Corpsetaker (conditional)
  • Silvermoon Guardian
  • Tol'vir Stoneshaper (conditional in Elemental decks)
  • Scarlet Crusader
  • Wickerflame Burnbristle
  • Tainted Zealot
  • Argent Squire
  • Righteous Protector

Paladin can also give Divine Shield to minions in multiple ways:

  • Grimestreet Protector
  • Steward of Darkshire
  • Argent Protector
  • Selfless Hero
  • Hand of Protection

Wild Format

Paladin has access some additional Wild-only Divine Shield minions:

  • Force-Tank MAX
  • Master Jouster (conditional)
  • Cobalt Guardian (only when summoning Mechs)
  • Argent Horserider
  • Fjola Lightbane (when targeted with spells)
  • Silent Knight
  • Annoy-o-Tron
  • Shielded Minibot

Paladin also has even more ways to give minions Divine Shield in Wild:

  • Enhance-o Mechano (randomly)
  • Coghammer
  • Seal of Champions

Knights of the Frozen Throne

Want to learn more about Hearthstone's upcoming Knights of the Frozen Throne? Head on over to our expansion guide.

hh.text: Your end of turn effects trigger twice.
hh.name: Drakkari Enchanter
hh.flavor_text: Drakkari sorceresses have the irritating habit of repeating themselves at the end of every sentence. Every sentence.
hh.guide:
Drakkari Enchanter is an Epic Neutral card from Knights of the Frozen Throne expansion. It is a three-mana 1/5 minion with a special effect to trigger your end of turn effects twice.

While one attack is not much, five Health on Drakkari Enchanter makes it somewhat durable. Obviously, with the statline it has, the only reason to include it in the deck is its effect. There are surprisingly many end-of-turn effects in Hearthstone: even in Standard format, there are more than 20 of them!

If you have sufficiently powerful end-of-turn effects, or can even build a lethal combo around such effects, Drakkari Enchanter can be a powerful addition.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

Drakkari Enchanter is the first card that enables guaranteed two ticks of discounts from Emperor Thaurissan. As such, it has potential to help or enable new combos in Wild format.

Drakkari Enchanter does not work with effects that have been determined to happen at the end of the turn by a Battlecry (Echoing Ooze) or a Deathrattle (Dreadsteed).

Standard Format

Drakkari Enchanter is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in spring 2019.

End of turn effects in Standard format with a Drakkari Enchanter on the board:

Mage:

  • Ethereal Arcanist: If you control a Secret, gain +4/+4

Paladin:

  • Grimestreet Enforcer: Give all minions in your hand +2/+2
  • Ragnaros, Lightlord: Restore eight Health to two damaged friendly characters (can target the same character twice, if it is still damaged after the first heal)

Priest:

  • Shadow Ascendant: Give two other random friendly minions +1/+1 (can target the same minion twice)

Shaman:

  • Healing Totem: Restore two Health to friendly minions
  • Mana Tide Totem: Draw two cards
  • Primalfin Totem: Summon two 1/1 Murlocs

Warlock:

  • Blood Imp: Give two other friendly minions +1 Health (can target the same minion twice)
  • Despicable Dreadlord: Deal two damage (one and one) to all enemy minions 
  • Kabal Trafficker: Add two random Demons to your hand
  • Nether Portal from Lakkari Sacrifice Quest: Summon four 3/2 Imps

Warrior:

  • Grimy Gadgeteer: Give two random minions in your hand +2/+2 (can target the same minion twice)

Neutral:

  • Baron Geddon: Deal four damage (two and two) to all other characters
  • Cobalt Scalebane: Give two other random friendly minions +3 Attack (can target the same minion twice)
  • Friendly Bartender: Restore two Health to your Hero
  • Gruul: Gain +2/+2
  • Hogger: Summon two 2/2 Gnolls with Taunt
  • Imp Master: Deals two damage to itself and summons two 1/1 Imps
  • Master Swordsmith: Give two other random friendly minions +1 Attack (can target the same minion twice)
  • Moroes: Summon two 1/1 Stewards
  • The Lich King: Add two random Death Knight cards to your hand
  • Twilight Elder: Give your C’Thun +2/+2
  • Ysera: Add two Dream Cards to your hand
  • Y'Shaarj, Rage Unbound: Put two minions from your deck into the battlefield
  • Young Priestess: Give two other friendly minions +1 Health (can target the same minion twice)

Wild Format

End of turn effects only in Wild format with a Drakkari Enchanter on the board:

Hunter:

  • Dreadscale: Deal two damage (one and one) to all other minions

Rogue:

  • Iron Sensei: Give two other friendly Mechs +2/+2 (can target the same minion twice)

Shaman:

  • Vitality Totem: Restore eight Health to your Hero

Warlock:

  • Fel Cannon: Deal two damage to two non-Mech minions (can target the same minion twice)

Warrior:

  • Obsidian Destroyer: Summon two 1/1 Scarabs with Taunt

Neutral:

  • Emperor Thaurissan: Reduce the cost of cards in your hand by two
  • Illuminator: If you control a Secret, restore eight Health to your Hero
  • Kel'Thuzad: Summon two copies of all friendly minions that died this turn
  • Ragnaros the Firelord: Deal eight damage to two random enemies (can target the same enemy twice if it survives the first hit)

hh.guide:
Card Review by Stonekeep.

This card is incredibly slow. You pay 8 mana for a 6/6 minion that does nothing right away and has no guaranteed value whatsoever. You summon a 0/8 Treasure Chest for your opponent and, after you kill it, you get a very powerful reward. While indeed, those reward cards are very good, you need to put a lot of resources into getting one. It's not like Kazakus, which has a weak body, but you get a powerful spell right away, you need to work hard to get it. Historically we've learned that high cost Legendaries that are very slow aren't really good. The biggest problem is always that a card like that does little to nothing against Aggro or faster Midrange decks. Not only an 8 mana 6/6 is nigh unplayable, but on top of that you probably won't even have time to deal with that Chest. You will want to use your removals and attacks to kill the minions that are threatening you, not to take down a 0 attack minion. The fact that two out of those cards aren't that great against faster decks doesn't really help.

The card is very good in a Control vs Control matchup, but you can say the same thing about a number of other high cost Legendaries that see zero play. Even against Control it's not an "auto-win" unless you can clear the Chest right away - remember that Silence exists. And remember that tempo is important even in slower matchups.

The class that has a highest chance of running it is probably Priest. Not only it has Shadow Word: Pain to deal with it (other classes can use Crazed Alchemist, but that's not really a great card to put into a Control deck), but they can perform some shenanigans - stealing it with Potion of Madness, buffing with Divine Spirit + Inner Fire and smacking opponent for a lot of damage etc. It will also die to Shadow Word: Horror if you have no way to remove it right away. That said, even in Priest it just feels too slow.

I think that The Lich King is simply a better 8-drop, because of the Taunt and better stats (more tempo). And it still gets some value in Control matchups, as the Death Knight cards are quite solid (not as good as Marin's, of course). And even Lich King doesn't see that much play, because it's too slow.

Good news is that we will get this card live on Monday, which means that we'll have a plenty of time to test it. Even if the card won't turn out to be good, I think that they should release cards mid-expansions more often.

Card rating: 1.5/5

hh.text: Battlecry: Adapt.
hh.name: Pterrordax Hatchling
hh.flavor_text: Aww.  So cute.  Want to feed him another finger?
hh.guide:
Pterrordax Hatchling is a common Neutral card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a three mana 2/2 minion with Adapt Battlecry.

Adapt applies a buff to a minion. It works in a similar way to Discover: you are presented with three options to choose from. There are ten adaptations to choose from, and each adaptation is independent from any previous ones, so if you Adapt a minion multiple times, you may be presented with the same options.

The ten possible adaptations are:

  • Crackling Shield (Divine Shield)

  • Flaming Claws (+3 Attack)

  • Living Spores (Deathrattle: Summon two 1/1 minions)

  • Lightning Speed (Windfury)

  • Liquid Membrane (Can’t be targeted by spells or Hero Powers)

  • Massive (Taunt)

  • Volcanic Might (+1/+1)

  • Rocky Carapace (+3 Health)

  • Shrouding Mist (Stealth until your next turn)

  • Poison Spit (Poisonous)

Adapt does not take into account any abilities the minion already has, so you can be offered Taunt when adapting a minion that already has Taunt, rendering that option useless. Many Adapt options stack, so you can safely pick up +3 Attack multiple times, but some of them do nothing when picked a second time: Divine Shield (unless the previous shield has already been lost), Windfury, Can’t be targeted by spells or Hero Powers, Taunt, Stealth (unless the previous Stealth has been spent), and Poisonous. Note that the Deathrattle to summon 1/1 minions does stack, so you can build a large board from a single minion after a couple of Adapts.

The probability to be offered a specific adaptation is 30%. If you Adapt a minion twice, the probability to be offered a specific adaptation at least once is 51%. The probability to find two specific adaptations in two attempts, however, is only 16%, so getting that Stealth and Windfury combo or any other specific two-ability combo is unlikely.

Standard Format

Pterrordax Hatchling is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

hh.guide:
Volcanosaur is a rare Neutral card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a seven mana 5/6 minion with Adapt twice Battlecry.

Adapt applies a buff to a minion. It works in a similar way to Discover: you are presented with three options to choose from. There are ten adaptations to choose from, and each adaptation is independent from any previous ones, so if you Adapt a minion multiple times, you may be presented with the same options.

The ten possible adaptations are:

  • Crackling Shield (Divine Shield)

  • Flaming Claws (+3 Attack)

  • Living Spores (Deathrattle: Summon two 1/1 minions)

  • Lightning Speed (Windfury)

  • Liquid Membrane (Can’t be targeted by spells or Hero Powers)

  • Massive (Taunt)

  • Volcanic Might (+1/+1)

  • Rocky Carapace (+3 Health)

  • Shrouding Mist (Stealth until your next turn)

  • Poison Spit (Poisonous)

Adapt does not take into account any abilities the minion already has, so you can be offered Taunt when adapting a minion that already has Taunt, rendering that option useless. Many Adapt options stack, so you can safely pick up +3 Attack multiple times, but some of them do nothing when picked a second time: Divine Shield (unless the previous shield has already been lost), Windfury, Can’t be targeted by spells or Hero Powers, Taunt, Stealth (unless the previous Stealth has been spent), and Poisonous. Note that the Deathrattle to summon 1/1 minions does stack, so you can build a large board from a single minion after a couple of Adapts.

The probability to be offered a specific adaptation is 30%. If you Adapt a minion twice, the probability to be offered a specific adaptation at least once is 51%. The probability to find two specific adaptations in two attempts, however, is only 16%, so getting that Stealth and Windfury combo or any other specific two-ability combo is unlikely.

Standard Format

hh.name: Sated Threshadon
hh.flavor_text: Bet you can't eat just one murloc!
hh.description: Hearthstone's ⁨Sated Threshadon⁩ is a ⁨Minion⁩ from the ⁨Journey to Un'Goro⁩ expansion.

hh.text: Battlecry: Discover a Secret.
hh.name: Hydrologist
hh.flavor_text: Murloc hydrologists are pretty rare.  Most murloc undergrads pick computer science.
hh.guide:
Hydrologist is a common Paladin class card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a two-mana 2/2 Murloc minion with a Battlecry to Discover a Secret.

The Discover mechanic allows you to choose one of three randomly selected cards. Each of the three cards that are offered are different. Unless otherwise noted on the card, it is only possible to Discover cards that are either neutral or from your own class. If your class has Secrets, Hydrologist will Discover a Secret from your own class. If your class has no Secrets, Hydrologist will Discover a Paladin Secret.

Hydrologist’s 2/2 stats for two mana are mediocre, but combined with its effect they are good enough to compete in both tempo and value.

Hydrologist is a strong card for just about any Paladin deck. As a Murloc, it is a natural inclusion for any Paladin deck that uses Murloc synergies, whether those decks are aggressive or midrange decks. Its effect is powerful enough that it can also find a spot in Paladin decks that do not otherwise include any Murlocs.

Paladin Secrets are generally considered to be fairly weak, but Hydrologist is able to turn them into major assets:

  • The Secret is generated by the Hydrologist, so it does not take up a card spot from the deck

  • The Secrets are good against different things, and the flexibility to choose one of three means that you are more likely to find a Secret suitable for the current matchup than if you’d just have a Secret directly in your deck

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

Discovering Eye for an Eye can be a win condition against many Mage decks: if you can get them down to one health, they have no way to damage you without killing themselves while you have Eye for an Eye active. Mage decks that run Alexstrasza as an offensive tool can use it to heal themselves to get rid of this conundrum, but other than that Mage has but a few tools to deal with the situation. Eater of Secrets as a tech card can also save the Mage, but that’s about it. If your own health is low when you play Eye for an Eye, Mage can go for a draw with a single, big damage spell, such as Pyroblast (ten damage).

Paladin often runs many cards that are good with Getaway Kodo. The ability to replay Battlecry effects (Hydrologist itself, Aldor Peacekeeper, Stonehill Defender, Gentle Megasaur, Sunkeeper Tarim, Primordial Drake), general buffs (Murloc Warleader), and even some Deathrattle minions (Tirion Fordring) can give the Paladin a big value advantage.

Paladin also often runs cards that are good with Redemption, such as Wickerflame Burnbristle, Murloc Warleader, and Tirion Fordring. Minions with Divine Shield are especially good with Redemption, as when they are resummoned with one health, they also have a Divine Shield for some additional protection.

If Hungry Crab is a popular tech card in the meta, Hydrologist can be a liability in a non-Murloc Paladin deck, as it then gives Hungry Crab a target where there is otherwise none. However, given the overall power of Hydrologist, this only becomes a problem if Hungry Crabs are extremely common.

Standard Format

Hydrologist is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

There are currently only five Paladin Secrets in Standard format. The probability to be offered any specific one is 60%.

The Standard Paladin Secrets are:

  • Eye for an Eye

  • Getaway Kodo

  • Noble Sacrifice

  • Redemption

  • Repentance

There are eight Mage Secrets (37.5% to be offered a specific one) and seven Hunter Secrets (43% to be offered a specific one), should you somehow acquire a Hydrologist to play with those classes.

Wild Format

There are eight Paladin Secrets in Wild format. The probability to be offered any specific one is 37.5%.

The Wild-only Paladin Secrets are:

  • Avenge

  • Competitive Spirit

  • Sacred Trial

There are ten Mage Secrets (30% to be offered a specific one) and nine Hunter Secrets (33.33% to be offered a specific one) , should you somehow acquire a Hydrologist to play with those classes.

"Ville "Old Guardian" Kilkku is an analytical Hearthstone content creator and a regular legend player on the EU server. In addition to his articles, you can find his Hearthstone videos on Youtube and stream on Twitch. If you have any questions or comments, you can connect with him on Twitter.

hh.text: Taunt Battlecry: Set all other minions' Attack and Health to 3.
hh.name: Sunkeeper Tarim
hh.flavor_text: Ironically, his favorite number is 4.
hh.guide:
Sunkeeper Tarim is a legendary Paladin class card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a six-mana 3/7 minion with Taunt and a Battlecry to set the attack and health of all other minions on the board to three.

Sunkeeper Tarim is an immensely powerful card, able to swing games around almost by itself. It sees play in all Paladin archetypes from aggro to control. As it is a 3/7 Taunt itself and sets all other minions to 3/3 stats, it can potentially deal with three affected minions before letting any through.

Sunkeeper Tarim can be used to buff your own minions, turning a board full of tokens into a significant threat. It can also be used to negate opponent’s threats, turning big minions and even big Jade Golems into a much more manageable size.

Sunkeeper Tarim is stronger when you have more minions on the board, the current stats of the minions do not matter. Before playing Sunkeeper Tarim, it is a good idea to take any value trades available on the board: all of the minions will have 3/3 stats anyway, so if you can destroy an opponent’s minion and leave your own alive, even if at just one health, you will get an additional 3/3 on the board compared to the opponent when Tarim comes down. Any small minions can also trade one for one against opponent’s big minions after Tarim: they will all have the same stats at that point.

If you are looking to maximize face damage on your Tarim turn, attack with any minions with more than three attack first, the play Sunkeeper Tarim, and then attack with any minions that had less than three attack before Tarim was played.

The mere existence of Sunkeeper Tarim forces the opponent to play around the chance that all minions on the board will be set to 3/3 stats. Therefore, many players choose to keep a Paladin’s board relatively clear (out of respect for Tarim, but also out of respect for Spikeridged Steed) and are careful not to overextend on the board with multiple big minions. Board-flooding token decks, on the other hand, are more happy to have plenty of minions on the board, as having all those minions can prevent the Paladin from playing Tarim (they need to watch out for Consecration and Primordial Drake instead).

Silencing a minion affected by Tarim’s effect returns it to its original stats.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

Stonehill Defender can Discover additional copies of Sunkeeper Tarim. In Standard, the probability to be offered Sunkeeper Tarim is 21% and in Wild it is 18%.

Note that any on-board buffs are applied on the minions after Tarim’s effect. Therefore, a Murloc Warleader can enable a number of value trades, as your Murlocs will have 5/4 stats whereas the opponent’s minions will have 3/3 stats.

Vinecleaver can be a powerful card to combo with Sunkeeper Tarim. Swinging with Vinecleaver summons two 1/1 minions, which can then be buffed to 3/3 stats with Tarim.

Sunkeeper Tarim can enable trades with weapons. Rallying Blade, TTruesilver Champion, and Vinecleaver are all capable of dealing with a three-health minion. If you have a Vinecleaver though, you would really want to summon the 1/1 minions before Tarim, but sometimes removing a minion is just too important.

Keeper of Uldaman (Wild) has the same effect as Sunkeeper Tarim, but only on a single minion, whereas Tarim affects all minions on the board.

Standard Format

Sunkeeper Tarim is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

Wild Format

There are a lot more cards that summon or affect Silverhand Recruits in Wild format than in Standard, such as Muster for Battle, Quartermaster, and Justicar Trueheart. Sunkeeper Tarim can support these token strategies based on the Paladin Hero Power extremely well.

hh.text: Battlecry: Choose a friendly minion. Summon a 1/1 copy of it.
hh.name: Mirage Caller
hh.flavor_text: Mirage is actually the name of its long-lost cat.
hh.guide:
Mirage Caller is a rare Priest class card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a three-mana 2/3 minion with a Battlecry to choose a friendly minion and summon a 1/1 copy of it.

The minion from Mirage Caller is summoned, not played, and therefore any Battlecry effects are not triggered. Therefore, Mirage Caller is typically used to summon copies of minions with other powerful effects, such as Deathrattles.

However, Mirage Caller can also be used to create large minions in conjunction with Silence effects: if the 1/1 minion summoned by Mirage Caller is Silenced, it regains the original stats of the minion. Naturally, it also loses any special effects, such as Deathrattles.

If you summon a copy of a Silenced minion with Mirage Caller, the copy is also Silenced but with 1/1 stats. However, the minion still counts as a summoned minion of its type and effect, for example as a Deathrattle minion. If you then Silence the copy again, its stats return to the original stats of the minion.

Mirage Caller can be powerful if you have a strong minion on the board for it to copy. However, as you are limited to summoning copies of your own minions only and not your opponent’s minions, it is a highly situational card that typically only sees play in decks that are built to have strong synergies with it.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

The Priest Journey to Un’Goro Quest, Awaken the Makers, requires you to summon Deathrattle minions. Therefore, copies of Deathrattle minions summoned by Mirage Caller count towards Quest completion. Copies of Silenced Deathrattle minions also count towards Quest completion.

At three mana, Mirage Caller is cheap enough to be combined with many powerful minions late in the game, such as Cairne Bloodhoof (six mana for Cairne and three mana for Mirage Caller for a total of nine mana) and Twilight Summoner (four mana for Twilight Summoner and three mana for Mirage Caller for a total of seven mana). Alas, such plays are heavily value-oriented and sacrifice a lot of tempo, which can make them unviable against any faster decks.

Standard Format

Mirage Caller is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

hh.text: Deathrattle: Return this to your hand as a 6/6 that costs (6).
hh.name: Pyros
hh.flavor_text: If you strike her down, she shall become more powerful than you can possibly… well, she'll become a 6/6 anyways.
hh.guide:
Pyros is a legendary Mage class card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a two-mana 2/2 Elemental minion with a Deathrattle to return to your hand as a 6/6 Elemental minion that costs six mana. This second form of Pyros also has a Deathrattle, this time to return to your hand as a 10/10 Elemental minion that costs ten mana. This third and final form of Pyros has no Deathrattle.

All forms of Pyros are mediocre compared to their mana cost and have no special effects, and individual minions like that never see play. The real value of Pyros is that it gives you three such minions in a single card: it enables decent tempo while also generating card advantage.

All forms of Pyros are Elemental minions and can be used to activate Elemental synergies.

Pyros is a popular value card because its initial form only costs two mana and can therefore be used to contest the board against aggressive decks. Many other value cards only come into play later.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

Pyros has good synergy with N'Zoth, the Corruptor: both the 2/2 Pyros and the 6/6 Pyros are resummoned by N’Zoth, and they both give you additional Pyros’ to your hand when they are destroyed. Therefore, you can play a total of three ten-mana 10/10 minions in a single game with Pyros and N’Zoth combo.

Pyros can be a liability when playing against Priest. If Priest steals the 2/2 Pyros with a Potion of Madness and is able to destroy it while stolen, the more powerful form of Pyros is returned to the Priest’s hand. Likewise, Priest can steal the 2/2 Pyros with a Cabal Shadow Priest.

Pyros does not work very well with Spiritsinger Umbra: Pyros is immediately destroyed and returned to your hand in its more powerful form when played on a board with Spiritsinger Umbra.

Pyros does not work with Baron Rivendare (Wild). Only one Pyros is returned to hand. The same applies to other return-to-hand effects, such as Spirit Echo: only one copy of a minion can be returned to hand.

Standard Format

Pyros is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

hh.text: Deathrattle: Copy a card from your opponent's deck and add it to your hand.
hh.name: Crystalline Oracle
hh.flavor_text: Being made of light has its disadvantages, but at least it's always looking on the bright side.
hh.guide:
Crystalline Oracle is a rare Priest class card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a one-mana 1/1 Elemental minion with a Deathrattle to copy a random card from your opponent’s deck and add it to your hand.

The card that Crystalline Oracle copies is from the opponent’s remaining deck. Therefore, if your opponent has no cards remaining in the deck, you will get nothing. It is important to play Crystalline Oracle before fatigue – and potentially resummon it before fatigue – in order to ensure that you get a card.

Sometimes it is possible to gain greater value from Crystalline Oracle later in the game if your opponent has means to add cards into their deck: you then have a chance to get a copy of those added cards that can be very powerful. Usually, however, Crystalline Oracle is an early-game card.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

The effect of Crystalline Oracle is identical to the effect of Shifting Shade, just in a smaller body.

Crystalline Oracle synergizes well with both the Priest Quest, Awaken the Makers, which requires you to summon Deathrattle minions, and with N'Zoth, the Corruptor, which resummons Deathrattle minions.

As Crystalline Oracle is an Elemental, Priest can Discover new copies of it from Servant of Kalimos. Class cards are more likely to be Discovered, and the probability to find a Crystalline Oracle is 36%.

Standard Format

Crystalline Oracle is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

hh.text: Your spells cost (1) less.
hh.name: Radiant Elemental
hh.flavor_text: It's a literal lava lamp!
hh.guide:
Radiant Elemental is a common Priest class card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a two-mana 2/3 Elemental minion that makes your spells cost one less mana while it remains on the board unsilenced.

Priest does not have many strong two-mana minions available to it, and therefore Radiant Elemental can fill several roles in a Priest deck: it can be used as a proactive play on Turn two, it can be used for its Elemental synergies, and it can be used for its powerful cost-reduction effect.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

The effect of Radiant Elemental is identical to the Mage class card Sorcerer's Apprentice.

Radiant Elemental can be a strong play on Turn two, as it reduces the mana cost of Power Word: Shield to zero, thus allowing you to play both for two mana for a 2/5 minion and cycling a card.

Radiant Elemental is often combined with Lyra the Sunshard, the Priest legendary minion from Journey to Un’Goro, as reducing the cost of spells enables you to play more spells together with Lyra and gain plenty of additional resources that way.

It can also be used to enable faster combos, such as creating a huge minion with Divine Spirit(s) and Inner Fire.

As Radiant Elemental is an Elemental, Priest can Discover new copies of it from Servant of Kalimos. Class cards are more likely to be Discovered, and the probability to find a Radiant Elemental is 36%.

Standard Format

Radiant Elemental is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

hh.text: Battlecry: Look at 3 cards. Guess which one started in your opponent's deck to get a copy of it.
hh.name: Curious Glimmerroot
hh.flavor_text: George promised to be good. But it's easy for little Glimmerroots to forget.
hh.guide:
Curious Glimmerroot is an epic Priest class card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a three-mana 3/3 minion with a Battlecry to look at three cards and guess which one started in your opponent’s deck. If you guess correctly, you get a copy of the card.

Despite the selection interface looking similar, it is important to note that this is not a Discover effect! Only one card of the three is from your opponent’s deck, and if you pick the wrong one, you do not get a card.

The cards that are offered are ones that started in your opponent’s deck. This includes any cards that have already been played, so if you are offered a card that you have already seen played (that was not generated during the game) you can be confident that it is the correct option.

The cards that are offered are class cards as long as your opponent had at least one class card in their deck. If they had no class cards, you are offered neutral cards, which does not happen in real games. Because class cards are generally more powerful than neutral cards, Curious Glimmerroot’s effect is slightly stronger than gaining simply any random card from your opponent’s deck.

In addition to the card itself, Curious Glimmerroot provides information: only one of the three cards is from the opponent’s deck, and therefore the other two cards are not from their deck. When you see common tech cards that end up not being the right choice, you gain information that your opponent does not have those cards in their deck.

The selection animation shows you which card would have been the right choice if you pick a wrong one.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

Curious Glimmerroot can be compared to Thoughtsteal: both cost three mana with Thoughtsteal giving you two random cards from the opponent’s deck and Curious Glimmerroot giving you one random class card from the opponent’s deck as well as the 3/3 minion on the board. It is, therefore, better for tempo, which is usually very important in Hearthstone.

Standard Format

Curious Glimmerroot is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

hh.text: Taunt Deathrattle: Give a random friendly minion +1/+1.
hh.name: Tortollan Shellraiser
hh.flavor_text: A hero... In a half-shell.
hh.guide:
Tortollan Shellraiser is a common Priest class card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a four-mana 2/6 minion with Taunt and a Deathrattle to give a random friendly minion +1/+1.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

While it is overall a somewhat mediocre card, Tortollan Shellraiser is one of the few Taunt minions with Deathrattle, especially in Standard format where Sludge Belcher and Deathlord are not available. This makes it a potential inclusion in Quest Priest or Deathrattle Priest decks that run Awaken the Makers and/or N'Zoth, the Corruptor.

Standard Format

Tortollan Shellraiser is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

There are currently three minions with both Taunt and Deathrattle available to Priest in Standard format: Tortollan Shellraiser, Infested Tauren, and Abomination. Tortollan Shellraiser is generally considered to be the strongest of the three.

Wild Format

In Wild format, Tortollan Shellraiser faces competition from Deathlord and Sludge Belcher, two very powerful Taunt minions with Deathrattle. Therefore, it is a much less attractive card to include in your deck in Wild.

hh.text: Battlecry: Destroy a friendly minion to Adapt twice.
hh.name: Ravenous Pterrordax
hh.flavor_text: For better results, feed your pterrordax low-fat, high-fiber minions.
hh.guide:
Ravenous Pterrordax is a common Warlock class card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a four mana 4/4 minion that destroys a friendly minion to Adapt twice.

If there is no minion on the board you can destroy (your board is empty or the minions you have are untergettable, e.g. in Stealth), then Ravenous Pterrordax is just a 4/4 with no effect.

Adapt applies a buff to a minion. It works in a similar way to Discover: you are presented with three options to choose from. There are ten adaptations to choose from, and each adaptation is independent from any previous ones, so if you Adapt a minion multiple times, you may be presented with the same options.

The ten possible adaptations are:

  • Crackling Shield (Divine Shield)

  • Flaming Claws (+3 Attack)

  • Living Spores (Deathrattle: Summon two 1/1 minions)

  • Lightning Speed (Windfury)

  • Liquid Membrane (Can’t be targeted by spells or Hero Powers)

  • Massive (Taunt)

  • Volcanic Might (+1/+1)

  • Rocky Carapace (+3 Health)

  • Shrouding Mist (Stealth until your next turn)

  • Poison Spit (Poisonous)

Adapt does not take into account any abilities the minion already has, so you can be offered Taunt when adapting a minion that already has Taunt, rendering that option useless. Many Adapt options stack, so you can safely pick up +3 Attack multiple times, but some of them do nothing when picked a second time: Divine Shield (unless the previous shield has already been lost), Windfury, Can’t be targeted by spells or Hero Powers, Taunt, Stealth (unless the previous Stealth has been spent), and Poisonous. Note that the Deathrattle to summon 1/1 minions does stack, so you can build a large board from a single minion after a couple of Adapts.

The probability to be offered a specific adaptation is 30%. If you Adapt a minion twice, the probability to be offered a specific adaptation at least once is 51%. The probability to find two specific adaptations in two attempts, however, is only 16%, so getting that Stealth and Windfury combo or any other specific two-ability combo is unlikely.

Standard Format

Ravenous Pterrordax is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

hh.text: Deathrattle: Go dormant. Play 4 cards in a turn to revive this minion.
hh.name: Sherazin, Corpse Flower
hh.flavor_text: A Tortollan gardener's worst nightmare.
hh.guide:
Sherazin, Corpse Flower is a legendary Rogue class card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a four-mana 5/3 minion with a Deathrattle to go dormant. When Sherazin goes dormant, it is replaced on the board by Sherazin, Seed, which has no stats. Sherazin, Seed is untargetable and immune to any effects. When you play four cards in a single turn, Sherazin, Seed is transformed back to Sherazin, Corpse Flower.

It is important to note that Sherazin does not have Charge. When it is revived, it suffers from summoning sickness and must wait until your next turn to attack.

Sherazin is not a card you can build your deck around. You get more value from Sherazin the earlier you play it, and if you need to draw through your entire deck to find it, you will simply not have enough cards left to revive it multiple times.

Sherazin is nonetheless a powerful card. Miracle Rogue decks are known to be able to revive Sherazin three, four, or even five times in a single game, which makes it a potent win condition against slower decks.

Sherazin, Seed is revived after you play your fourth card of the turn. The effect of the card takes place before Sherazin is revived, which can be useful when playing a board clear that revives Sherazin on an empty board afterwards.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

While Sherazin, as a deathrattle minion, looks like a good fit for a N’Zoth deck, it is not as simple to use in one as it seems. If Sherazin is revived too many times, you may receive a board full of Sherazins when you play N'Zoth, the Corruptor. If the opponent is able to deal with that board, you may have only one spot on the board (the one where N’Zoth was played) for minions other than Sherazin and that can make it difficult to revive all the Sherazins.

If you use a powerful board-clear spell, such as Vanish or Twisting Nether, as the fourth card to revive Sherazin, the effect of the spell happens first, and Sherazin is revived after that on an empty board.

If a spell gets countered by Counterspell, it does not count towards reviving Sherazin.

Sherazin does not work very well with Spiritsinger Umbra. Sherazin is immediately destroyed and replaced with Sherazin, Seed when played on a board with Spiritsinger Umbra on it. Similarly, forcing the Sherazin's Deathrattle with cards like Terrorscale Stalker turns it into Sherazin, Seed immediately with no upside whatsoever.

Any minions that have Sherazin’s Deathrattle become Sherazin, Seed when destroyed and revive into the full 5/3 Sherazin. This happens for 1/1 copies of Sherazin summoned by Barnes as well as Unearthed Raptors (Wild) that have copied the Deathrattle from Sherazin.

There used to be a bug that counted some cards as two cards for the purpose of reviving Sherazin (cards with transformation effects, such as Faceless Manipulator). The bug was fixed in June 2017.

Standard Format

Sherazin, Corpse Flower is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

hh.flavor_text: Briefly tried stand-up comedy under the name "Stonehill Offender", but turtles are just too thin-skinned.
hh.guide:
Stonehill Defender is a rare neutral card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a three-mana 1/4 minion with Taunt and a Battlecry to Discover a Taunt minion.

The Discover mechanic allows you to choose one of three randomly selected cards. It is more probable to be offered cards from your own class: they are weighted four times as much as neutral cards. Each of the three cards that are offered are different.

Unless otherwise noted on the card, it is only possible to Discover cards that are either neutral or from your own class. Full details on the minions Stonehill Defender can Discover are in sections below for both Standard format and Wild format.

The class Taunt minions of Paladin and Shaman are exceptionally strong, and Stonehill Defender has a good chance to Discover one of them: in Standard format, it does so more than two times out of three, and in Wild format it does so almost two times out of three. Therefore, it is exceptionally strong in those classes.

The class where Stonehill Defender is most likely to Discover a class minion is Warrior, but the overall quality of Warrior Taunt minions is inferior to those of Paladin and Shaman. Stonehill Defender can still be a strong addition to a Warrior deck, especially Taunt Warrior.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

Stonehill Defender has good synergy with Evolve. As a three-mana minion that has low stats, it will almost always gain a significant buff from Evolve.

Stonehill Defender is one of the most important cards for completing Warrior’s Fire Plume's Heart quest. As it is a Taunt minion that Discovers another Taunt minion, you get to advance the quest by two with just one card.

hh.text: Battlecry: Add a random minion with 5 or more Attack to your hand.
hh.name: Tortollan Forager
hh.flavor_text: In the Tortollan tongue, Un’goro is known as the “Land of the Lost and Found.”
hh.guide:
Tortollan Forager is a common Druid class card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a two-mana 2/2 minion with a Battlecry to add a random minion with five or more attack to your hand. This random minion can be from any class.

While Tortollan Forager provides the Druid with an early-game minion to contest the board with that also generates additional resources, it can be difficult to find a spot for it in most Druid decks. The more aggressive Druid decks want to utilize minions that are better for tempo, and the slower Druid decks want to ramp up their mana crystals in the early game.

A minion with five or more attack can sound like a powerful minion, but there is a lot of variation on what you get from Tortollan Forager. Even in Standard format, there are more than 100 minions that you can get, and hitting a good minion is completely random. You can usually expect the minion to cost five or more mana and have at least mediocre stats for its mana cost: many minions with effects – both strong and weak – tend to have a fairly low attack value.

The real question is whether you need the 2/2 body of the Tortollan Forager for anything. If you want to play powerful and expensive minions, why not put them directly into your deck? So far, the answer has usually been that Tortollan Forager is not really needed for decks that want to go for the end game.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

Any minion received from Tortollan Forager’s Battlecry can be used to advance the Jungle Giants quest.

Any minion received from Tortollan Forager’s Battlecry synergizes with the Battlecry effect of Elder Longneck and the Deathrattle of Giant Anaconda.

Standard Format

Tortollan Forager is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

There are 137 minions you can get from Tortollan Forager in Standard format:

  • Roughly a seven-mana 6/6 on average (83 minions – 61% – cost between five and seven mana)

  • 17 minions with Taunt (12%)

  • 8 minions with an unconditionally useful Deathrattle (6%)

  • 4 minions with unconditional Charge (3%)

Wild Format

There are 228 minions you can get from Tortollan Forager in Wild format.

  • 139 minions – 61% – cost between five and seven mana

  • 21 minions with Taunt (9%)

  • 17 minions with an unconditionally useful Deathrattle (7%)

  • 4 minions with unconditional Charge (2%)

hh.text: Battlecry: Discover a spell and cast it with random targets.
hh.name: Tortollan Primalist
hh.flavor_text: I see pizza in my future.
hh.guide:
Tortollan Primalist is an epic neutral card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is an eight-mana 5/4 minion with a Battlecry to Discover a spell and cast it with random targets.

The Discover mechanic allows you to choose one of three randomly selected cards. Each of the three cards that are offered are different. Unless otherwise noted on the card, it is only possible to Discover cards that are either neutral or from your own class. For example, playing Tortollan Primalist as a Warlock therefore lets you Discover a Warlock spell that is then cast on a random, legal, target.

You can almost always gain some value from Tortollan Primalist thanks to the Discover mechanic: if you select a spell that cannot have bad targets – say, a Cabalist's Tome or Flamestrike as Mage – you are guaranteed a well-targeted spell. Pay attention to the exact wording of the spell: many damage spells can be cast on friendly targets and many buff spells can be cast on enemies, and you may end up swinging the game in the wrong direction.

The targets are determined assuming the player to be the one who casts the spell. Any effects that target enemy minions will therefore always target the opponent’s minions, never your own. Effects that can target any minions can target either friendly or enemy minions.

If you play Tortollan Primalist in a Shaman deck and choose a spell with Overload, the Overload is applied to you.

However, the spell is considered to be cast by the minion for other purposes, so it does not buff a Mana Wyrm, for example.

Tortollan Primalist’s 5/4 stats for eight mana are simply terrible. They are barely worth four mana, so you would need to reliably get a lot of value from Tortollan Primalist in order to justify a spot in the deck for it. This value simply does not exist, so Tortollan Primalist does not see much play.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

Tortollan Primalist can be compared to Servant of Yogg-Saron and Yogg-Saron, Hope's End himself. However, there are some key differences: The spell cast by Tortollan Primalist is Discovered, which avoids the worst options, and Tortollan Primalist can only cast spells from your own class. It is therefore much more reliable than Servant of Yogg-Saron, but you pay three mana for that reliability.

Standard Format

Tortollan Primalist is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

hh.guide:
Gentle Megasaur is an epic Neutral card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a four mana 5/4 minion that Adapts your Murlocs. 

Adapt applies a buff to a minion. It works in a similar way to Discover: you are presented with three options to choose from. There are ten adaptations to choose from, and each adaptation is independent from any previous ones, so if you Adapt a minion multiple times, you may be presented with the same options.

The ten possible adaptations are:

  • Crackling Shield (Divine Shield)

  • Flaming Claws (+3 Attack)

  • Living Spores (Deathrattle: Summon two 1/1 minions)

  • Lightning Speed (Windfury)

  • Liquid Membrane (Can’t be targeted by spells or Hero Powers)

  • Massive (Taunt)

  • Volcanic Might (+1/+1)

  • Rocky Carapace (+3 Health)

  • Shrouding Mist (Stealth until your next turn)

  • Poison Spit (Poisonous)

Adapt does not take into account any abilities the minion already has, so you can be offered Taunt when adapting a minion that already has Taunt, rendering that option useless. Many Adapt options stack, so you can safely pick up +3 Attack multiple times, but some of them do nothing when picked a second time: Divine Shield (unless the previous shield has already been lost), Windfury, Can’t be targeted by spells or Hero Powers, Taunt, Stealth (unless the previous Stealth has been spent), and Poisonous. Note that the Deathrattle to summon 1/1 minions does stack, so you can build a large board from a single minion after a couple of Adapts.

The probability to be offered a specific adaptation is 30%. If you Adapt a minion twice, the probability to be offered a specific adaptation at least once is 51%. The probability to find two specific adaptations in two attempts, however, is only 16%, so getting that Stealth and Windfury combo or any other specific two-ability combo is unlikely.

Standard Format

Gentle Megasaur is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

hh.text: Battlecry: If you played an Elemental last turn, cast an Elemental Invocation.
hh.name: Kalimos, Primal Lord
hh.flavor_text: All that's missing is a little heart.
hh.guide:
Kalimos, Primal Lord is a legendary Shaman class card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is an eight-mana 7/7 Elemental minion with a Battlecry to cast an Elemental Invocation if you played an Elemental on the previous turn.

The available Elemental Invocations are:

  • Invocation of Air: Deal 3 damage to all enemy minions

  • Invocation of Earth: Fill your board with 1/1 Elementals

  • Invocation of Water: Restore 12 health to your hero

  • Invocation of Fire: Deal 6 damage to the enemy hero

When you play Kalimos with its effect active, you get to choose the Elemental Invocation to be cast from all four options.

Kalimos fits the description of a desirable high-cost minion in Hearthstone: a nice body with an immediate effect. Furthermore, it is extremely flexible with its effect: it can deal area-of-effect damage, summon tokens, heal your Hero, or deal damage to the opponent’s Hero. With such a level of flexibility, Kalimos is able to find a spot in almost any Shaman deck that can reliably fulfill its Battlecry condition.

Kalimos itself is also an Elemental, and can, therefore, activate Elemental synergies for the following turn.

The Elemental synergy cards enable counterplay: Because the effect is only active if a player played an Elemental on the previous turn, both players know which turns Kalimos can be played together with its effect, and which turns the effect cannot be used, and plan their moves accordingly.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

If you have Hallazeal the Ascended on the board, Kalimos’s Invocation of Air area-of-effect damage heals your Hero. This is peculiar, because Kalimos’s Elemental Invocations do not benefit from Spell Damage or count as spells for the purpose of buffing certain minions, such as Red Mana Wyrm.

Kalimos is an Elemental, so it buffs Ozruk, should you choose to play it the following turn. However, note that Ozruk requires minions to be played, not summoned, and therefore any 1/1 Elementals summoned by Kalimos do not buff Ozruk.

Servant of Kalimos can Discover additional copies of Kalimos. The probability to be offered Kalimos as a Shaman is 19% in Standard and 15% in Wild.

Standard Format

Kalimos, Primal Lord is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

"Ville "Old Guardian" Kilkku is an analytical Hearthstone content creator and a regular legend player on the EU server. In addition to his articles, you can find his Hearthstone videos on Youtube and stream on Twitch. If you have any questions or comments, you can connect with him on Twitter.

hh.text: Battlecry: If you played an Elemental last turn, Discover an Elemental.
hh.name: Servant of Kalimos
hh.flavor_text: He's doing his best, but his mom thinks that if he had just applied himself in school Kalimos would be working for HIM.
hh.guide:
Servant of Kalimos is a rare neutral card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a five-mana 4/5 Elemental minion with a Battlecry to Discover an Elemental minion, if you played an Elemental on the previous turn.

The Discover mechanic allows you to choose one of three randomly selected cards. It is more probable to be offered cards from your own class: they are weighted four times as much as neutral cards. Each of the three cards that are offered are different.

Unless otherwise noted on the card, it is only possible to Discover cards that are either neutral or from your own class. Class-specific Discover probabilities are in the Standard Format and Wild Format sections below.

Servant of Kalimos itself is also an Elemental, and can therefore activate Elemental synergies for the following turn.

Elemental synergy cards enable counterplay: Because the effect is only active if a player played an Elemental on the previous turn, both players know which turns Servant of Kalimos can be played together with its effect, and which turns the effect cannot be used, and plan their moves accordingly.

Servant of Kalimos is a strong value card that also has reasonable stats and the Elemental tribal tag to keep Elemental synergies active. It is a strong choice for any Elemental decks.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

Because there are not that many Elemental minions, Servant of Kalimos is quite good at Discovering specific class minions: in Standard format, it has a 53% chance to Discover Ragnaros, Lightlord for Paladin, 33% to Discover Lyra the Sunshard for Priest, 33% to Discover Pyros for Mage, and 19% to Discover Kalimos, Primal Lord for Shaman.

Standard Format

Servant of Kalimos is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

There are 37 Elemental minions in the Standard format. However, as Servant of Kalimos can only Discover cards that are either neutral or from your own class, the Discover probabilities vary by class.

Elemental minions in Standard format:

Neutral (15):

  • Arcane Anomaly

  • Fire Fly

  • Glacial Shard

  • Volatile Elemental

  • Igneous Elemental

  • Magma Rager

  • Tar Creeper

  • Fire Plume Phoenix

  • Servant of Kalimos

  • Frost Elemental

  • Frozen Crusher

  • Baron Geddon

  • Blazecaller

  • Stormwatcher

  • Ozruk

Shaman (12):

  • Air Elemental

  • Dust Devil

  • Fire Plume Harbinger

  • Jade Spirit

  • Hot Spring Guardian

  • Unbound Elemental

  • Hallazeal the Ascended

  • Earth Elemental

  • Fire Elemental

  • Stone Sentinel

  • Al'Akir the Windlord

  • Kalimos, Primal Lord

For Shaman, the probability to be offered a specific class minion is 19%, and the probability to be offered at least one class minion is 99%. The probability to be offered a specific neutral minion is 5%.

Mage (5):

  • Pyros

  • Shimmering Tempest

  • Steam Surger

  • Water Elemental

  • Anomalus

For Mage, the probability to be offered a specific class minion is 33%, and the probability to be offered at least one class minion is 93%. The probability to be offered a specific neutral minion is 9%.

Priest (5):

  • Crystalline Oracle

  • Radiant Elemental

  • Mana Geode

  • Lightspawn

  • Lyra the Sunshard

For Priest, the probability to be offered a specific class minion is 33%, and the probability to be offered at least one class minion is 93%. The probability to be offered a specific neutral minion is 9%.

Druid (1):

  • Jade Spirit

Paladin (1):

  • Ragnaros, Lightlord

Rogue (1):

  • Jade Spirit

Warlock (1):

  • Tar Lurker

Warrior (1):

  • Tar Lord

For Druid, Paladin, Rogue, Warlock, and Warrior, the probability to be offered the class minion is 53%. The probability to be offered a specific neutral minion is 16%.

For classes with no class Elementals, the probability to be offered a specific neutral Elemental is 20%.

Wild Format

There are 46 Elemental minions in the Standard format. However, as Servant of Kalimos can only Discover cards that are either neutral or from your own class, the Discover probabilities vary by class.

The Elementals available only in Wild format are:

Neutral (3):

  • Ice Rager

  • Djinni of Zephyrs

  • Ragnaros the Firelord

Shaman (3):

  • Neptulon

  • Fireguard Destroyer

  • Rumbling Elemental

Therefore, the Discover probabilities for Wild format are as follows:

For Shaman, the probability to be offered a specific class minion is 15%, and the probability to be offered at least one class minion is 99%. The probability to be offered a specific neutral minion is 4%.

For Mage, the probability to be offered a specific class minion is 30%, and the probability to be offered at least one class minion is 90%. The probability to be offered a specific neutral minion is 8%.

For Priest, the probability to be offered a specific class minion is 30%, and the probability to be offered at least one class minion is 90%. The probability to be offered a specific neutral minion is 8%.

For Paladin, Warlock, and Warrior, the probability to be offered the class minion is 47%. The probability to be offered a specific neutral minion is 14%.

For classes with no class Elementals, the probability to be offered a specific neutral Elemental is 17%.

"Ville "Old Guardian" Kilkku is an analytical Hearthstone content creator and a regular legend player on the EU server. In addition to his articles, you can find his Hearthstone videos on Youtube and stream on Twitch. If you have any questions or comments, you can connect with him on Twitter.

hh.text: Battlecry: Discover a spell. Deal damage to your hero equal to its Cost.
hh.name: Chittering Tunneler
hh.flavor_text: Ear to the ground, he carefully interpreted the chittering noises: “You wanna cast a spell? I wanna cast a spell!”
hh.guide:
Chittering Tunneler is an epic Warlock class card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a three-mana 3/3 Beast minion with a Battlecry to Discover a spell and deal damage to your Hero equal to the cost of the selected spell.

The Discover mechanic allows you to choose one of three randomly selected cards. Each of the three cards that are offered are different. Unless otherwise noted on the card, it is only possible to Discover cards that are either neutral or from your own class. Playing Chittering Tunneler as a Warlock, therefore, lets you Discover a Warlock spell.

As your opponent sees how much damage you take from Chittering Tunneler, they can have a rough idea of what spell you picked. The damage is always equal to the base mana cost of the spell.

Taking damage for Discovering spells is not particularly attractive. Luckily, more than half of Warlock spells cost three mana or less, so you are almost guaranteed to have some cheap options available.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

Violet Illusionist can make you immune during your own turn, and then you will take no damage from Chittering Tunneler’s Discover effect.

Standard Format

Chittering Tunneler is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

There are 24 Warlock spells (and the Quest, which cannot be discovered) in Standard format. The probability to be offered a specific card is 12.5%.

Zero mana (2):

  • Forbidden Ritual

  • Sacrificial Pact

One mana (3):

  • Corruption

  • Mortal Coil

  • Soulfire

Two mana (4):

  • Bloodbloom

  • Corrupting Mist

  • Demonfire

  • Renounce Darkness

Three mana (5):

  • Bloodfury Potion

  • Drain Life

  • Sense Demons

  • Shadow Bolt

  • Spreading Madness

Four mana (3):

  • Blastcrystal Potion

  • Hellfire

  • Shadowflame

Five mana (3):

  • Bane of Doom

  • Feeding Time

  • Kara Kazham!

Six mana (2):

  • Felfire Potion

  • Siphon Soul

Eight mana (1):

  • Twisting Nether

Ten mana (1):

  • DOOM!

Wild Format

There are 33 Warlock spells (and the Quest, which cannot be discovered) in Wild format. The probability to be offered a specific card is 9%.

In addition to the cards available in Standard format, there are the following spells in Wild:

One mana (1):

  • Power Overwhelming

Two mana (3):

  • Curse of Rafaam

  • Darkbomb

  • Demonfuse

Three mana (1):

  • Demonwrath

hh.text: Whenever you discard this, give it +2/+2 and return it to your hand.
hh.name: Clutchmother Zavas
hh.flavor_text: A bit of a snob: still refuses to drive anything with automatic transmission.
hh.guide:
Clutchmother Zavas is a legendary Warlock class card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a two-mana 2/2 Beast minion with a special effect that whenever you discard it, it gains +2/+2 and is returned back to your hand.

While Clutchmother Zavas can grow to an impressive size if it gets discarded a couple of times – how would you like an 8/8 for two mana, for example – its real strength does not lie in its appearance on the board, but in its appearance in the hand.

Every time Clutchmother Zavas is discarded instead of another card, it means that you have one more card at your disposal. Effectively, it is the same as drawing a card. Would you like to have a card that, if kept in your hand, allowed you to draw more cards when you play cards? That’s basically what Zavas does.

Clutchmother Zavas is a great card for any decks that rely heavily on the discard mechanic. The discard mechanic itself, however, has generally been somewhat underwhelming: You generally have to find discard synergy cards to combo with the discard cards, and even then you need those discards to hit the right cards in your hand to make them worthwhile. Careful hand size management can help, but most of the time you still have non-synergy cards in your hand at all times and there is a risk of discarding just the wrong cards.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

If Clutchmother Zavas is resurrected, for example by a Cruel Dinomancer, it always comes out as a 2/2, regardless of the stats it had when it was destroyed or discarded.

Malchezaar's Imp is particularly powerful with Clutchmother Zavas: it draws you a new card when Zavas is discarded, and then Zavas returns back to your hand.

Clutchmother Zavas can help complete Lakkari Sacrifice: as only cards that are actually discarded from the hand advance the quest – you cannot advance it by playing a discard card from an otherwise empty hand – Zavas can help keep cards in your hand to ensure quest credit.

Standard Format

Clutchmother Zavas is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

Standard cards available to Warlock that discard cards:

  • Soulfire

  • Darkshire Librarian

  • Succubus

  • Lakkari Felhound (discards two)

  • Doomguard (discards two)

  • Deathwing (discards your whole hand)

Wild Format

Wild-only cards available to Warlock that discard cards:

  • Dark Bargain (discards two)

hh.text: Battlecry: Destroy all cards in your deck that cost (3) or less.
hh.name: Hemet, Jungle Hunter
hh.flavor_text: The goblin travel agency lost his luggage, but he's still having a great vacation!
hh.guide:
Hemet, Jungle Hunter is a legendary neutral card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a six-mana 6/6 minion with a Battlecry to destroy all cards in your deck that cost three mana or less.

The first thing to remember when evaluating Hemet is that whenever you can add consistency to your deck, it is a good thing. That is the reason you add multiple copies of cards to your deck, and why cards that allow you to manipulate your deck are so good.

Hemet adds a lot of consistency to your draws, as it removes all of your unused early-game cards from your deck. It also brings you closer to fatigue, but decks that want Hemet are generally not too concerned about fatigue anyway.

Effective use of Hemet requires planning your deck around it: you need to plan which cards will be destroyed by Hemet and which ones will remain. The first competitive deck that used Hemet was the early iteration of Burn Mage, which was designed so that only direct damage cards remained in the deck after playing Hemet. This ensured that every card drawn from that point on was able to potentially end the game.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

The most obvious combo for Hemet is to make a Paladin deck with cards that cost less than four mana except for Holy Wraths and Molten Giants. After playing Hemet, you will only have Holy Wrath and Molten Giant in the deck, and if you can get the Holy Wrath to draw Molten Giant, it will deal 25 damage. Alas, the combo is highly unreliable and gimmicky at best.

In a Quest Hunter deck, Hemet, Jungle Hunter can be played after completing The Marsh Queen quest and before playing Queen Carnassa to destroy unnecessary low-cost cards from your deck. It is important to note that if you play Hemet after shuffling in Carnassa's Brood, they will also be destroyed by Hemet’s effect, rendering it useless and thus making Hemet unplayable after playing Queen Carnassa.

In a Quest Druid deck, Hemet, Jungle Hunter does not destroy the zero-cost minions discounted by the Barnabus the Stomper from your deck, if their base cost is four or more. Therefore, it can be used to get rid of cheap spells after quest completion, if you find yourself needing that.

Standard Format

Hemet, Jungle Hunter is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

Wild Format

While not exactly competitive, Hemet can potentially combo with Astral Communion. By removing all the cheap cards, but unfortunately not the second copy of Astral Communion, Hemet can improve the consistency of draws after playing Astral Communion.

"Ville "Old Guardian" Kilkku is an analytical Hearthstone content creator and a regular legend player on the EU server. In addition to his articles, you can find his Hearthstone videos on Youtube and stream on Twitch. If you have any questions or comments, you can connect with him on Twitter.

After you cast a spell on
this minion, summon a
1/1 Plant and cast
another copy on it.
hh.name: The Voraxx
hh.flavor_text: I am the Voraxx.  I speak for the weeds.
hh.guide:
The Voraxx is a legendary neutral card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a four-mana 3/3 minion with a special effect that after you cast a spell on The Voraxx, it summons a 1/1 minion and casts another copy of the spell on it.

Even though The Voraxx is a neutral minion, most classes have no real way to use it. Only Paladin, Druid, and Priest have multiple buff spells that are good with The Voraxx. Rogue has Cold Blood, and it can get more buff spells if playing against one of the three aforementioned classes, but when playing against anything else, it can hardly buff The Voraxx.

If The Voraxx dies from the spell you cast, it will not summon a 1/1 minion or cast a spell. There is usually no reason to cast a harmful spell on The Voraxx though.

There are some powerful plays available with The Voraxx, but buffed minions in general have multiple weaknesses, particularly silence effects and transformation effects (Devolve is a nightmare to The Voraxx). You also need to find the combo, The Voraxx and the appropriate buff spell, at the same time.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

The Voraxx does not synergize with Paladin’s The Last Kaleidosaur quest: the spell cast on the 1/1 minion is cast by The Voraxx, not the player, and does not advance the quest.

The Voraxx can be a powerful play on Turn Ten together with Spikeridged Steed: summoning a 5/9 Taunt minion and a 3/7 Taunt minion, both with a Deathrattle to summon a 2/6 Taunt minion.

Standard Format

The Voraxx is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

Standard Druid spells that are good with The Voraxx:

  • Earthen Scales

  • Mark of the Wild

  • Mark of Y'Shaarj (does not draw a card)

  • Mark of Nature (applies the same buff on both The Voraxx and the 1/1 minion – if Fandral is on the board, applies both buffs to both minions)

  • Moonglade Portal (summons two random six-cost minions)

Standard Paladin spells that are good with The Voraxx:

  • Hand of Protection

  • Divine Strength

  • Blessing of Wisdom

  • Blessing of Might

  • Adaptation (selected separately, from different options, for The Voraxx and the 1/1 minion)

  • Silvermoon Portal

  • Blessing of Kings

  • Blessed Champion

  • Spikeridged Steed

  • Dinosize

Standard Priest spells that are good with The Voraxx:

  • Binding Heal (heals your Hero twice)

  • Power Word: Shield (draws two cards)

  • Divine Spirit (Inner Fire also kind of works, but The Voraxx casts its copy on a new 1/1 minion, so it only buffs The Voraxx)

  • Power Word: Tentacles

Wild Format

Wild-only Druid spells that are good with The Voraxx:

  • Dark Wispers

Wild-only Paladin spells that are good with The Voraxx:

  • Seal of Champions

Wild-only Priest spells that are good with The Voraxx:

  • Power Word: Glory

  • Velen's Chosen

hh.text: Deathrattle: Add a random Mage spell to your hand.
hh.name: Shimmering Tempest
hh.flavor_text: HATES being summoned for Kirin Tor party lighting.
hh.guide:
Shimmering Tempest is a common Mage class card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a two-mana 2/1 Elemental minion with a Deathrattle to add a random Mage spell to your hand.

With only one health at two mana, Shimmering Tempest is a weak minion that relies on its Elemental tribal tag and Deathrattle effect to see any play. These two factors enable it to see niche play, but it is not one of the strongest Mage cards.

Shimmering Tempest can be used to activate Elemental synergies while also generating additional resources. Alas, there are so many Mage spells in the game that getting a random one is unlikely to provide an answer to the current situation in the game. Therefore, Shimmering Tempest is a general value card – Mage spells are pretty good overall – not a card to get just the right answer from.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

The Deathrattle of Shimmering Tempest works identically with the Battlecry of Babbling Book. Babbling Book is generally considered to be a superior card, because Battlecry effects are more reliable to activate and Babbling Book is also cheaper.

Spells received from Shimmering Tempest count towards Open the Waygate quest.

Getting a random spell is much less powerful than being able to Discover a spell. Primordial Glyph is a staple whereas Shimmering Tempest is way less popular.

Shimmering Tempest can be a liability when playing against Priest. If Priest steals Shimmering Tempest with a Potion of Madness and is able to destroy it while stolen, the Priest receives the random Mage spell. Likewise, Priest can steal Shimmering Tempest with a Cabal Shadow Priest. However, if you are playing Elemental Mage, a Priest player will likely save at least one steal effect for Pyros.

Standard Format

Shimmering Tempest is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

There are 31 Mage spells in Standard format (and the Quest, which cannot be received from a random effect). Therefore, the chance to get any individual spell is 3%.

Other key probabilities:

  • Direct damage to Hero (7): 55% (Arcane Missiles, Flame Geyser, Frostbolt, Fireball, Firelands Portal, Greater Arcane Missiles, Pyroblast)

  • Area-of-effect damage (6): 49% (Arcane Explosion, Volcanic Potion, Cone of Cold, Blizzard, Meteor, Flamestrike)

  • Secret (8): 61% (Counterspell, Ice Barrier, Ice Block, Mana Bind, Mirror Entity, Potion of Polymorph, Spellbender, Vaporize)

  • Freeze (5): 42% (Freezing Potion, Frostbolt, Frost Nova, Cone of Cold, Blizzard)

Standard Mage spells:

Zero mana (2):

  • Forbidden Flame

  • Freezing Potion

One mana (2):

  • Arcane Missiles

  • Mirror Image

Two mana (5):

  • Arcane Explosion

  • Flame Geyser

  • Frostbolt

  • Primordial Glyph

  • Shatter

Three mana (11):

  • Arcane Intellect

  • Counterspell

  • Frost Nova

  • Ice Barrier

  • Ice Block

  • Mana Bind

  • Mirror Entity

  • Potion of Polymorph

  • Spellbender

  • Vaporize

  • Volcanic Potion

Four mana (4):

  • Fireball

  • Molten Reflection

  • Polymorph

Five mana (1):

  • Blizzard

  • Meteor

Seven mana (3):

  • Firelands Portal

  • Flamestrike

  • Greater Arcane Missiles

Ten mana (1)

  • Pyroblast

Wild Format

There are 42 Mage spells in Wild format (and the Quest, which cannot be Discovered). Therefore, the chance to Discover any individual spell is 2%.

Other key probabilities:

  • Direct damage to Hero (9): 52% (Arcane Missiles, Flame Geyser, Frostbolt, Forgotten Torch, Fireball, Dragon's Breath, Firelands Portal, Greater Arcane Missiles, Pyroblast)

  • Area-of-effect damage (6): 38% (Arcane Explosion, Volcanic Potion, Cone of Cold, Blizzard, Meteor, Flamestrike)

  • Secret (10): 57% (Counterspell, Duplicate, Effigy, Ice Barrier, Ice Block, Mana Bind, Mirror Entity, Potion of Polymorph, Spellbender, Vaporize)

  • Freeze (6): 38% (Freezing Potion, Ice Lance, Frostbolt, Frost Nova, Cone of Cold, Blizzard)

Wild-only Mage spells:

One mana (2):

  • Arcane Blast

  • Ice Lance

Two mana (2):

  • Flamecannon

  • Unstable Portal

  • Duplicate

hh.text: Battlecry: Shuffle a sealed Un'Goro pack into your deck.
hh.name: Elise the Trailblazer
hh.flavor_text: Reno taught her that blazing her own trail is a lot more fun than following someone else's map.
hh.guide:
Elise the Trailblazer is a legendary neutral card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a five-mana 5/5 minion with a Battlecry to shuffle an Un'Goro Pack to your deck. Un’Goro Pack is a two-mana spell that adds five random Journey to Un’Goro cards to your hand.

The Un’Goro Pack spell is similar to opening card packs. You receive five Journey to Un’Goro cards, and the cards can be from any class. There is always at least one card of epic rarity or better in the Un’Goro Pack, and on average you receive one legendary card per Un’Goro Pack. It is common to receive even multiple legendary cards from a single Un’Goro Pack. You cannot receive Quest cards from Un’Goro Pack.

This provides you with amazing refill later in the game – five cards all at once at the cost of two mana – while also leaving the opponent guessing what you can do afterwards. As you can gain cards from any class, you can potentially unlock powerful combos by combining different class cards.

If you do not have enough space in your hand for five cards, you will receive as many cards as fit in your hand (maximum hand size is ten cards). The animation will also only display the cards that you get.

It is important to note that these cards are only for use in the ongoing game – cards are not added to your collection, you do not get to keep the cards permanently.

Elise the Trailblazer is a strong value minion for control decks and slower midrange decks. A 5/5 body for five mana is reasonably good, and if the game goes on long enough for you to find the Un’Goro Pack, the value from the Pack is phenomenal.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

The Priest class card Shadow Visions can Discover additional copies of Un’Goro Pack after it has been shuffled into the deck. It is common for Priest to be able to play multiple Un’Goro Packs in any long game.

There are 126 cards that you can receive from Un’Goro Pack: there are 135 cards in the expansion, of which nine are Quest cards that are ineligible.

The exact probabilities to receive various types of cards cannot be calculated, as we do not know exactly how rarity affects the odds of getting cards from Un’Goro Pack. We know it has an effect, because at least one epic is guaranteed.

On average, you will receive one of the 14 non-Quest legendary cards in the set:

  • Tyrantus

  • King Mosh

  • Ozruk

  • Kalimos, Primal Lord

  • Swamp King Dred

  • Hemet, Jungle Hunter

  • Sunkeeper Tarim

  • Elise the Trailblazer

  • Lyra the Sunshard

  • Sherazin, Corpse Flower

  • Spiritsinger Umbra

  • The Voraxx

  • Clutchmother Zavas

  • Pyros

There are not that many filler cards among Journey to Un’Goro legendary cards, so you are likely to get a good one.

There are 92 minions, 31 spells, and three weapons among the cards you can get. There are 24 Elementals, so you have a good chance to be able to activate any Elemental synergy cards you get with another Elemental. There are also 34 Beasts and four Murlocs.

There is only one Secret in Journey to Un’Goro, the Mage Secret Mana Bind. Therefore, if you see a Secret being played from Un’Goro Pack, you know it can only be Mana Bind. You can also get a Secret indirectly from Un’Goro Pack by getting a Hydrologist and using it to Discover a Secret.

Standard Format

Elise the Trailblazer is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

"Ville "Old Guardian" Kilkku is an analytical Hearthstone content creator and a regular legend player on the EU server. In addition to his articles, you can find his Hearthstone videos on Youtube and stream on Twitch. If you have any questions or comments, you can connect with him on Twitter.
