hh.text: Can't be targeted by spells or Hero Powers.
hh.name: Tyrantus
hh.flavor_text: Millennia of evolutionary pressures turned his species into the Faerie Dragons we know today.
hh.guide:
Tyrantus is a legendary Druid class card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a ten-mana 12/12 Beast minion that cannot be targeted by spells or Hero Powers.

Tyrantus cannot be targeted by spells or Hero Powers is a powerful effect, but it has its limitations. Tyrantus can still be destroyed by area-of-effect spells and abilities (such as Twisting Nether), random effects (such as Deadly Shot and Brawl), and Battlecry effects (such as Big Game Hunter).

The downside of Tyrantus is that it does not have an immediate effect on the game. Tyrantus is hard to destroy but easy to ignore, so if you are behind when playing it, it is hard to use it to come back and win. For a ten-mana minion, this is nearly a fatal flaw, and it prevents Tyrantus from seeing play in most decks.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

Because Tyrantus is a Beast and its ability does not prevent it from being targeted with Battlecry effects, it is possible to create a copy of Tyrantus with Menagerie Warden. This can make for a huge swing turn, especially when combined with Jungle Giants quest that can make either or both of them cost zero mana.

The Deathrattle of Giant Anaconda can pull Tyrantus from your hand to the board. Because of Tyrantus’ special ability, the opponent might not have an immediate way to deal with it.

Tyrantus also synergizes well with Y'Shaarj, Rage Unbound, as it has no Battlecry and therefore does not mind being summoned on the board instead of being played.

Standard Format

Tyrantus is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

Wild Format

In Wild format, you can even copy Tyrantus multiple times with Menagerie Warden in combination with Brann Bronzebeard.

"Ville "Old Guardian" Kilkku is an analytical Hearthstone content creator and a regular legend player on the EU server. In addition to his articles, you can find his Hearthstone videos on Youtube and stream on Twitch. If you have any questions or comments, you can connect with him on Twitter.
hh.description: Hearthstone's ⁨Tyrantus⁩ is a ⁨Minion⁩ from the ⁨Journey to Un'Goro⁩ expansion.

hh.text: After you summon a minion, trigger its Deathrattle effect.
hh.name: Spiritsinger Umbra
hh.flavor_text: She sees the fate of anyone she meets, but it's always the same: dinosaur attack.
hh.guide:
Spiritsinger Umbra is a legendary neutral card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a four-mana 3/4 minion with a special effect that triggers the Deathrattle effects of any minions you summon while Spiritsinger Umbra is on the board unsilenced.

Spiritsinger Umbra triggers the Deathrattle effects of any minions that are summoned, not only played. Therefore, it can be used with copy and summon effects and not just with cards played directly from hand.

While the effect of Spiritsinger Umbra is powerful, it can be difficult to use effectively. There are several neat plays available with Spiritsinger Umbra, but reliable and consistent plays where it plays a key role are hard to come by.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

Playing a Dreadsteed (Wild) on a board with Spiritsinger Umbra results in a full board of Dreadsteeds, as each one will summon another, which in turn summons another. A similar effect also happens if you play a Cruel Dinomancer and Cruel Dinomancer is the only minion you have discarded in the game: Cruel Dinomancers will summon new Cruel Dinomancers until the board is full.

Playing Living Mana while you have Spiritsinger Umbra on the board immediately returns your mana crystals (they are empty though). You will also gain additional mana crystals once the Treants die, so this can ramp up your mana if you are not yet at full mana.

Playing a Moat Lurker on a friendly minion while Spiritsinger Umbra is on the board will immediately resummon the minion. If it is a Deathrattle minion, its Deathrattle is also triggered.

Spiritsinger Umbra is powerful with Sylvanas Windrunner, immediately stealing a minion when Sylvanas is played.

Spiritsinger Umbra works well with Unearthed Raptor (Wild): the copied Deathrattle is triggered immediately when the Raptor is played.

Spiritsinger Umbra works well with N'Zoth, the Corruptor, as it immediately triggers the Deathrattles of all minions summoned by N’Zoth.

Spiritsinger Umbra does not work very well with Pyros and Sherazin, Corpse Flower. Both are immediately destroyed: Pyros returns to your hand in its more powerful form and Sherazin goes dormant.

Standard Format

Spiritsinger Umbra is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

"Ville "Old Guardian" Kilkku is an analytical Hearthstone content creator and a regular legend player on the EU server. In addition to his articles, you can find his Hearthstone videos on Youtube and stream on Twitch. If you have any questions or comments, you can connect with him on Twitter.

hh.text: Taunt Battlecry: Gain +5 Health for each Elemental you played last turn.
hh.name: Ozruk
hh.flavor_text: Between you and me, Ozruk is a bit obsessed with his body.
hh.guide:
Ozruk is a legendary neutral card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a nine-mana 5/5 Elemental minion with Taunt and a Battlecry to gain an additional five health for each Elemental you played on the previous turn.

Ozruk’s effect requires minions to be played, not just summoned, and therefore only minions played directly from hand buff his health.

Nonetheless, it is possible to buff Ozruk a fair bit by using cheap Elementals and Elemental tokens, such as Flame Elementals from Fire Fly and Igneous Elemental. If you manage to play, say, a 5/25 Ozruk, the opponent almost has to have some hard removal or a silence or transformation effect to deal with it.

Ozruk can be a bit difficult to use, as in order to justify the nine mana cost, you need to get it buffed by at least two Elemental minions. Playing two or more minions on a single turn is a fairly solid commitment to playing Ozruk the following turn, which reduces your flexibility.

Ozruk is not a popular card to put in a deck because of its high mana cost and the difficult setup required for it.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

Kalimos, Primal Lord and Stone Sentinel can summon additional Elemental minions on the board. However, because Ozruk requires minions to be played, not summoned, these additional minions do not buff Ozruk. Ozruk played on a turn after playing only a Stone Sentinel would have 5/10 stats: Stone Sentinel itself gives Ozruk five additional health, but the Rock Elementals it summons do not buff Ozruk further.

If Ozruk is buffed by only one minion, it has the same stats, 5/10, as Ancient of War, but it costs two more mana.

Standard Format

Ozruk is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

"Ville "Old Guardian" Kilkku is an analytical Hearthstone content creator and a regular legend player on the EU server. In addition to his articles, you can find his Hearthstone videos on Youtube and stream on Twitch. If you have any questions or comments, you can connect with him on Twitter.
hh.description: Hearthstone's ⁨Ozruk⁩ is a ⁨Minion⁩ from the ⁨Journey to Un'Goro⁩ expansion.

hh.text: Battlecry: Add a random Beast to your hand.
hh.name: Jeweled Macaw
hh.flavor_text: It’s not LITERALLY jeweled. The goblins were terribly disappointed.
hh.guide:
Jeweled Macaw is a common Hunter class card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a one-mana 1/1 Beast minion with a Battlecry that adds a random Beast to your hand. The random Beast can be from any class.

Hunters have plenty of cards that synergize with Beast minions, and a one-mana Beast can be useful in many situations to enable those synergies. Furthermore, Hunter as a class has poor card draw, which makes resource-generation very useful.

Jeweled Macaw is a strong candidate for any slower Hunter decks. For fast decks, the 1/1 body is not enough tempo to justify a spot in a deck that accepts that it either wins the game in a relatively short period of time or it runs out of resources. This keeps Jeweled Macaw from being part of all Hunter decks.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

Hunter has many cards that synergize with Beast minions, such as the following:

  • Tundra Rhino

  • Ram Wrangler (Wild)

  • Houndmaster

  • Kill Command

  • Scavenging Hyena

  • Stampede

A cheap Beast, such as Jeweled Macaw, enables playing a Beast and the synergy card on the same turn. That said, Hunter has a good selection of one-mana class-specific Beast minions: in addition to Jeweled Macaw, there’s Alleycat, Fiery Bat, Raptor Hatchling, Timber Wolf, and Webspinner (Wild). The toolbox from which Hunters can pick exactly the right card for their deck is therefore quite large.

Jeweled Macaw can be used to advance the Hunter Journey to Un’Goro Quest, The Marsh Queen, which requires you to summon one-mana minions. There is also a small chance (17% in Standard, 15% in Wild) that it generates another one-mana Beast minion to be used with the Quest.

Standard Format

Jeweled Macaw is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

There are 76 Beast minions in Standard format. Therefore, it is unlikely (1.3%) to get any specific one from Jeweled Macaw. What is interesting, however, is how likely it is to find some specific effects.

Mana cost:

  • One mana: 13 (17% to get one mana or cheaper)

  • Two mana: 11 (32% to get two mana or cheaper)

  • Three mana: 17 (54% to get three mana or cheaper)

  • Four mana: 7 (63% to get four mana or cheaper)

  • Five mana: 10 (76% to get five mana or cheaper)

  • Six mana: 5 (83% to get six mana or cheaper)

  • Seven mana: 6 (91% to get seven mana or cheaper)

  • Eight mana: 2

  • Nine mana: 3

  • Ten mana: 2

Taunt (7): 9.2% (Giant Mastodon, Ornery Direhorn, Direhorn Hatchling, Stegodon, Ironfur Grizzly, Silverback Patriarch, Stubborn Gastropod)

Poisonous (3): 3.9% (Emperor Cobra, Giant Wasp, Stubborn Gastropod)

Stealth (4): 5.3% (Sabretooth Stalker, Stranglethorn Tiger, Giant Wasp, Jungle Panther)

Sticky Deathrattle (5): 6.6% (Sated Threshadon, Savannah Highmane, Infested Wolf, Rat Pack, Kindly Grandmother)

Immediate damage to the opponent (5 without board, 7 with board): 6.6% without board, 9.2% with board (King Krush, Tundra Rhino, Dispatch Kodo, Emerald Reaver, Stonetusk Boar with board also Dire Wolf Alpha and Mukla, Tyrant of the Vale)

Even in Standard format, which includes fewer cards than Wild, the results from Jeweled Macaw vary so much that it is unlikely to find any specific thing you are looking for. The card is an overall value generator, not a way to dig for a specific answer.

Wild Format

There are 100 Beast minions in Wild format. Therefore, it is unlikely (1%) to get any specific one from Jeweled Macaw. What is interesting, however, is how likely it is to find some specific effects.

Mana cost:

  • One mana: 15 (15% to get one mana or cheaper)

  • Two mana: 16 (31% to get two mana or cheaper)

  • Three mana: 21 (52% to get three mana or cheaper)

  • Four mana: 13 (65% to get four mana or cheaper)

  • Five mana: 12 (77% to get five mana or cheaper)

  • Six mana: 6 (83% to get six mana or cheaper)

  • Seven mana: 10 (93% to get seven mana or cheaper)

  • Eight mana: 2

  • Nine mana: 3

  • Ten mana: 2

Taunt (9): 9% (Giant Mastodon, Ornery Direhorn, Direhorn Hatchling, King of Beasts, Stegodon, Fierce Monkey, Ironfur Grizzly, Silverback Patriarch, Stubborn Gastropod)

Poisonous (5): 5% (Maexxna, Emperor Cobra, Giant Wasp, Stubborn Gastropod, Pit Snake)

Stealth (4): 4% (Sabretooth Stalker, Stranglethorn Tiger, Giant Wasp, Jungle Panther)

Sticky Deathrattle (7): 7% (Sated Threshadon, Savannah Highmane, Infested Wolf, Rat Pack, Mounted Raptor, Kindly Grandmother, Haunted Creeper)

Immediate damage to the opponent (5 without board, 7 with board): 5% without board, 7% with board (King Krush, Tundra Rhino, Dispatch Kodo, Emerald Reaver, Stonetusk Boar with board also Dire Wolf Alpha and Mukla, Tyrant of the Vale)

Again, the results from Jeweled Macaw vary so much that it is unlikely to find any specific thing you are looking for. The card is an overall value generator, not a way to dig for a specific answer.

hh.text: Battlecry: Adapt a friendly Beast.
hh.name: Crackling Razormaw
hh.flavor_text: Wasn't clever enough to go AROUND the electric fence.
hh.guide:
Crackling Razormaw is a common Hunter class card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a two-mana 3/2 Beast minion with a Battlecry to Adapt a friendly Beast.

Adapt applies a buff to a minion. It works in a similar way to Discover: you are presented with three options to choose from. There are ten adaptations to choose from, and each adaptation is independent from any previous ones, so if you Adapt a minion multiple times, you may be presented with the same options.

The ten possible adaptations are:

  • Crackling Shield (Divine Shield)

  • Flaming Claws (+3 Attack)

  • Living Spores (Deathrattle: Summon two 1/1 minions)

  • Lightning Speed (Windfury)

  • Liquid Membrane (Can’t be targeted by spells or Hero Powers)

  • Massive (Taunt)

  • Volcanic Might (+1/+1)

  • Rocky Carapace (+3 Health)

  • Shrouding Mist (Stealth until your next turn)

  • Poison Spit (Poisonous)

Adapt does not take into account any abilities the minion already has, so you can be offered Taunt when adapting a minion that already has Taunt, rendering that option useless. Many Adapt options stack, so you can safely pick up +3 Attack multiple times, but some of them do nothing when picked a second time: Divine Shield (unless the previous shield has already been lost), Windfury, Can’t be targeted by spells or Hero Powers, Taunt, Stealth (unless the previous Stealth has been spent), and Poisonous. Note that the Deathrattle to summon 1/1 minions does stack, so you can build a large board from a single minion after a couple of Adapts.

The probability to be offered a specific adaptation is 30%. If you Adapt a minion twice, the probability to be offered a specific adaptation at least once is 51%. The probability to find two specific adaptations in two attempts, however, is only 16%, so getting that Stealth and Windfury combo or any other specific two-ability combo is unlikely.

Crackling Razormaw is one of the most powerful cards from Journey to Un’Goro. It requires you to have a Beast on the board to gain full value, but Hunter is a class that can often maintain a board presence. There is also an upside to the requirement: being able to Adapt a minion that is already on the board, and therefore possibly able to attack immediately, is much stronger than Adapting a minion that is just played and cannot do anything on its first turn.

Crackling Razormaw is powerful when played on curve on Turn Two, often buffing a one-mana minion significantly. However, it can be even more powerful when played later in the game for a major buff to a bigger minion. This level of power throughout the course of the game is rare for early-game minions, and it is one of the key reasons Crackling Razormaw is such a strong card.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

It is important that Crackling Razormaw has the Beast tag, as Hunter has many cards that synergize with Beast minions, such as the following:

  • Tundra Rhino

  • Ram Wrangler (Wild)

  • Houndmaster

  • Kill Command

  • Scavenging Hyena

  • Stampede

Finding the Poisonous Adapt can be huge. A Poisonous Wild Pyromancer wipes the entire board, as all damage from it is also Poisonous, including its area-of-effect damage. Likewise, a Poisonous Knife Juggler throws Poisonous knives.

However, as Crackling Razormaw can only Adapt Beasts, there is only one very niche case where Poisonous is useful beyond the obvious small minion killing a big minion: Crackling Razormaw can Adapt a Fiery Bat, and the Deathrattle of Fiery Bat is Poisonous as long as the Fiery Bat itself is alive. If the Fiery Bat dies, and the Deathrattle triggers, it is not Poisonous, but if the Deathrattle is triggered by Princess Huhuran or a similar effect, it is Poisonous.

Standard Format

Crackling Razormaw is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

hh.text: After your opponent plays a minion, attack it.
hh.name: Swamp King Dred
hh.flavor_text: Swamp King Dred, more like Swamp King Dead, amiright?
hh.guide:
Swamp King Dred is a legendary Hunter class card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a seven-mana 9/9 Beast minion with a special effect: after your opponent plays a minion, attack it.

Swamp King Dred’s effect is only triggered by minions that are played from hand, not by minions that are summoned. Therefore, Swamp King Dred will attack a played Alleycat, but it will not attack the Tabbycat summoned by the Alleycat. Swamp King Dred will also not attack any minions summoned by spells, such as Animal Companion or Firelands Portal.

Swamp King Dred is able to attack minions that cannot usually be attacked with its effect. Taunt means little to the King, as it will happily attack a minion played behind a Taunt minion. Trying to trade up by playing a Flametongue Totem when the opponent has a Swamp King Dred on the board is thus a bad idea: the King will immediately attack and destroy the Flametongue Totem even if there is a Taunt minion on the board. Stealth is also of no significance, a Stranglethorn Tiger will take the hit despite being hidden.

Swamp King Dred’s effect is triggered after Battlecry effects. Therefore, if Swamp King Dred is summoned on the board as the result of the Battlecry of an opponent’s minion, it will attack that minion. The most common occurrence is Dirty Rat pulling a Swamp King Dred from hand: the King will immediately dispose of the Dirty Rat.

However, there is one thing that can stop the King: freeze effects. A frozen Swamp King Dred does not attack played minions.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

Because Swamp King Dred’s effect is triggered after Battlecry effects, it is possible to play a self-buffing Adapt minion and try to find Poisonous with the Battlecry, which would then kill the King as it attacks the minion. Any naturally Poisonous minions also do the trick.

Sylvanas Windrunner (Wild) can be an effective counter to Swamp King Dred: the King will attack and kill Sylvanas, and if the King is its owner’s only minion on the board, Sylvanas’ Deathrattle is guaranteed to steal it.

If there is a Mayor Noggenfogger in play, Swamp King Dred will attack a random enemy character, possibly even the Hero, whenever the opponent plays a minion.

If there is a Redemption in play, Swamp King Dred will attack the minion played from hand, but not the minion resurrected by Redemption (Redemption is a summon effect, not a play effect).

Standard Format

Swamp King Dred is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

hh.text: Battlecry: Destroy all damaged minions.
hh.name: King Mosh
hh.flavor_text: He's a terror at concerts.
hh.guide:
King Mosh is a legendary Warrior class card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a nine-mana 9/7 Beast minion with a Battlecry to destroy all damaged minions.

There is a lot of strategy in using King Mosh:

  • If both players have minions on the board, you try to choose your trades so that the opponent’s minions are destroyed or damaged whereas as many of your own minions as possible stay unharmed.

  • You can try to damage individual minions to pick them off – if they are Taunt minions, it can open an opportunity for your other minions to attack whatever is protected by those Taunt minions, perhaps taking damage only after King Mosh has been played.

  • Setting up for a good King Mosh play can include damaging select minions already on the previous turn or even earlier.

King Mosh has seen only occasional play in Journey to Un’Goro metagame. However, there are definitely niches where it can be useful.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

Whirlwind can be combined with King Mosh for a board-clear effect that costs exactly ten mana. In Wild format, Death's Bite’s Deathrattle can be combined with King Mosh for a similar effect.

Blood To Ichor can be combined with King Mosh to effectively use King Mosh as an Execute that summons two minions and costs exactly ten mana. Inner Rage can achieve a similar effect with one less mana without summoning a small minion alongside Mosh.

If you set up a board clear with King Mosh over two turns, you can use Primordial Drake, Ravaging Ghoul, or Revenge (Wild) first and follow that up with King Mosh on the following turn.

As King Mosh is a Beast, The Curator can draw it from the deck. Combined with Primordial Drake, you can draw cards for both Turn eight and Turn nine with The Curator.

Deathwing is similar to King Mosh as a board-clear card: Deathwing, however, is unconditional but also costs your entire hand whereas King Mosh requires activation but does not discard your other cards. Both have their advantages and disadvantages.

King Mosh’s Battlecry kills a damaged Swamp King Dred before Dred has a chance to attack King Mosh.

King Mosh can kill itself with its Battlecry, but the circumstances to make that happen are possible almost only when intentionally set up, as most triggered effects take place only after the Battlecry: Snipe, for example, damages King Mosh only after the Battlecry. (In order to kill King Mosh with its own Battlecry, you need some kind of Illidan Stormrage and Knife Juggler setup to kill an Explosive Sheep or the like on the opponent’s side.)

Standard Format

King Mosh is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

hh.text: Battlecry: If you control another Murloc, Discover a Murloc.
hh.name: Primalfin Lookout
hh.flavor_text: Lookout is a self-appointed title that's mostly an excuse to beat things up.
hh.guide:
Primalfin Lookout is a common neutral card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a three-mana 3/2 Murloc minion with a Battlecry to Discover a Murloc, if you control another Murloc.

The Discover mechanic allows you to choose one of three randomly selected cards. It is more probable to be offered cards from your own class: they are weighted four times as much as neutral cards. Each of the three cards that are offered are different.

Unless otherwise noted on the card, it is only possible to Discover cards that are either neutral or from your own class. Paladin, Shaman, and Warlock have class-specific Murlocs that they can Discover with Primalfin Lookout, the other classes can only Discover neutral Murlocs.

Murlocs that buff or otherwise synergize well with other Murlocs are important for any decks that go all out on Murloc synergies. Primalfin Lookout provides an option to find more such Murlocs, so it is a potential inclusion for any full Murloc deck. The classes that typically use such decks are Paladin, Shaman, and Warlock.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

Primalfin Lookout will almost always find at least one strong Murloc, such as Murloc Warleader, Murloc Tidecaller, Bluegill Warrior, Rockpool Hunter, Coldlight Seer, another copy of itself, or Finja, the Flying Star.

Standard Format

Primalfin Lookout is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in Spring 2019.

There are 19 Murlocs in Standard format (14 neutral, 4 Paladin, and 1 Warlock):

  • Grimscale Chum (Paladin)

  • Grimscale Oracle

  • Murloc Raider

  • Murloc Tidecaller

  • Vilefin Inquisitor (Paladin)

  • Bilefin Tidehunter

  • Blowgill Sniper

  • Bluegill Warrior

  • Hydrologist (Paladin)

  • Murloc Tidehunter

  • Primalfin Champion (Paladin)

  • Rockpool Hunter

  • Coldlight Oracle

  • Coldlight Seer

  • Murloc Warleader

  • Primalfin Lookout

  • Seadevil Stinger (Warlock)

  • Finja, the Flying Star

  • Corrupted Seer

For Paladin, the probability to be offered a specific class Murloc is 38%, and the probability to be offered at least one class Murloc is 91%. The probability to be offered a specific neutral Murloc is 11%.

For Warlock, the probability to be offered the class Murloc is 55%. The probability to be offered a specific neutral Murloc is 17.5%.

For classes other than Paladin and Warlock, the probability to be offered a specific Murloc is 21.5%.

Wild Format

There are 25 Murlocs in Wild format. In addition to the Murlocs in Standard format, there are the following Murlocs in Wild:

  • Murloc Tinyfin

  • Sir Finley Mrrgglton

  • Puddlestomper

  • Siltfin Spiritwalker (Shaman)

  • Old Murk-Eye

  • Murloc Knight (Paladin)

For Paladin, the probability to be offered a specific class Murloc is 30%, and the probability to be offered at least one class Murloc is 90%. The probability to be offered a specific neutral Murloc is 8%.

For Shaman and Warlock, the probability to be offered the class Murloc is 47%. The probability to be offered a specific neutral Murloc is 14%.

For classes other than Paladin, Shaman, and Warlock, the probability to be offered a specific Murloc is 17%.

hh.text: Whenever you cast a spell, add a random Priest spell to your hand.
hh.name: Lyra the Sunshard
hh.flavor_text: Arise, fair sun, and kill my envious foes. They don't have a legendary as beautiful as you.
hh.guide:
Lyra the Sunshard is a legendary Priest class card from Hearthstone’s Journey to Un’Goro expansion. It is a five-mana 3/5 Elemental minion that adds a random Priest spell to your hand whenever you cast a spell.

Lyra the Sunshard is one of those cards that win games on its own. Priest decks typically include 11 to 14 spells, which is ample fuel for Lyra, so it can be added as an alternative win condition to most Priest decks.

Lyra is powerful, but looking for a specific spell can be an exercise in futility. Lyra does not win games by giving you a specific Priest spell, but by providing value in the form of spells that leave your opponent wondering what exactly to play around as well as requiring immediate removal that disrupts your opponent’s game plan. Looking for a damage or a healing spell right away very rarely succeeds.

There are three main ways to use Lyra:

  • Immense value generator, possibly together with Radiant Elementals, generating many spells in a single turn

  • Tempo play with one or two spells that gives you some additional resources and a minion on the board that requires the opponent’s immediate attention

  • Pseudo Taunt, perhaps without any additional spells, against an aggressive deck, threatening to generate healing spells if ignored

One reason to not include Lyra in your Priest deck is that you need to have spells in hand in order to gain value from Lyra. This promotes a more passive line of play where resources are conserved until key cards are drawn, and you may want to take a more active approach. Yet, Lyra is so good that it is usually necessary to justify not including it rather than justify including it.

Significant Interactions and Related Cards

Lyra is often played together with Radiant Elemental, as reducing the cost of spells enables you to play more spells and gain plenty of additional resources that way. This can enable long chains of spells, although as many Priest spells are reactive in nature, you might not be able to actually play them without a target.

The effect of Lyra takes place before the card text of the spell. For example, if you cast a Power Word: Shield with a full hand, Lyra generates a new card for you first, and then Power Word: Shield will attempt to draw a card, causing that card to be burned, because your hand is full. Likewise, if you kill off your own Lyra with a Dragonfire Potion, it will still generate a spell for you before dying. Lyra also generates a spell for you for any spells you cast that are interrupted by a Counterspell.

As Lyra is an Elemental, Priest can Discover new copies of Lyra from Servant of Kalimos. Class cards are more likely to be Discovered, and the probability of finding Lyra is 33%.

Standard Format

Lyra the Sunshard is part of Hearthstone Standard format. It will rotate out of Standard in spring 2019.

There are currently 30 Priest spells in Standard format (excluding the Quest, which cannot be created by Lyra), so the probability to receive any individual spell is 3.33% per spell cast. A Lyra that gets to generate four spells thus has a 13% chance to generate any specific spell. With ten attempts, this probability increases to 29%. Even with 30 attempts, the probability is still only around 64%.

Priest spells are generally fairly cheap, so playing Lyra together with a Radiant Elemental can enable long chains of spells: ten of the 30 spells cost one mana or less (zero with a single Radiant Elemental) and 16 of the 30 spells cost two mana or less (zero with two Radiant Elementals).

Wild Format

There are currently 40 Priest spells in Wild format (excluding the Quest, which cannot be created by Lyra), so the probability to receive any individual spell is 2.5% per spell cast. A Lyra that gets to generate four spells thus has a 9% chance to generate any specific spell. With ten attempts, this probability increases to 22%.

Priest spells are generally fairly cheap, so playing Lyra together with a Radiant Elemental can enable long chains of spells: 13 of the 40 spells cost one mana or less (zero with a single Radiant Elemental) and 22 of the 40 spells cost two mana or less (zero with two Radiant Elementals). The ratios are similar to those of Standard format, so expected chain lengths are also similar.

Available Wild-only spell sorted by cost (see Standard spells from the previous section):

One mana:

  • Flash Heal

  • Power Word: Glory

  • Light of the Naaru

Two mana:

  • Convert

  • Confuse

  • Resurrect

Three mana:

Five mana:

Six mana:

  • Lightbomb
